thinking.disposable_income: South Shore has relatively low income levels with median income of $39,649 and 56.5% of households making less than $50,000. This suggests high sensitivity to costs from fares, fees, and taxes
thinking.discretionary_consumption: With lower income levels and high percentage of households below $50,000, discretionary spending is likely limited. Additional transportation costs and taxes would significantly impact household budgets
thinking.accessibility: High transit dependency with 37.8% having no vehicle and 32.8% using transit for commuting. 49.8% drive alone, suggesting a mixed-mode community needing balance between transit and driving options
thinking.decision_rationale: 1. Prioritized proposals with lower transit fares ($0.75) given high transit usage and low incomes. 2. Favored moderate tax rates (1%) to maintain service quality while limiting burden. 3. Selected moderate driving fees ($0.50) to improve transit service without excessive impact on drivers. 4. Balanced travel time improvements with cost impacts. 5. Considered high percentage of both transit users and drivers in community
